title: Fraud and Friendship; or the orphan and the foundling of the King's printing-house. An Edinburgh tale. By the author of “Jessie Melville,” etc. [David Pae.]
author: Pae, David
snippet: That's owre i' the New Toon ; but it's no ill to find frae here. Just gang up till ye come to the Trone, that great big kirk stannin' by itsel'; then turn to yer richt, doon the North Biigg, and ye're at the end o' Princes Street; cross owre, and gang up a narrow street they ca' West Register Street. It has a gey wheen turns in it, but it lands ye in St Andrew's Square."

title: Memoir of Robert Chambers /
author: Chambers, William
snippet: The family depression during this gloomy period was felt more acutely by my brother than by myself, for, besides being more susceptible in feelings, he was, from his gentle and retiring habits, less able to face the stern realities with which we were unitedly environed. Left, as has been said, for a time in Peebles to pursue his studies at the grammar-school, he was finally brought to Edinburgh, and placed at a noted classical academy that of Mr Benjamin Mackay, in West Register Street, preparatory to being (if possible) sent to the university. There was an understanding in the family that, as the most suitable professional pursuit, he was to be prepared for the church.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: 56 LITERARY LANDMARKS OF EDINBURGH West Register Street by the narrow alley running now between the New Register House and the new Caf6 Royal. This little paved foot-path was, in the time of Ambrose's, a green lane called Gabriel's Road, leading diagonally across the New Town to Silvermills, and it is said still to claim its ancient privilege of a right of way.

title: Noctes ambrosianæ,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: This locality, which still bears the name by which in ancient times it was so bloodily baptised, is situated in the vicinity of West Register Street, at the back of the east end of Princes Street, and close to the Register Office. Here stood the tavern from which the Nodes Coenwque, commemorated in these volumes, derived their name.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: I pricked up my small ears at once, and with a quick look of intelligence, followed her out of the shop. We got as far as West Register Street, and then she suddenly pulled up. " Ah ! he's forgotten to put in the worsted jackets."
